name: electricity production, solar thermal parabolic trough, 50 MW | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18231/documentation

This activity represents the generation of electricity with a 50 MW solar thermal parabolic trough power plant in Upington, South Africa. This requires a fully constructed solar thermal parabolic trough and the required co-firing diesel fuel to run the plant. 

This activity starts with the concentrated solar power plant being operational and producing electricity. 

This activity does not show any operation&maintenance activities directly as these are already included in the supplying activities (e.g. oil use and disposal for maintenance of the pumps).
category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/351:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution/3510:Electric power generation, transmission and distribution

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from a dataset modelled for the location Upington, South Africa. Uncertainty has not been adjusted as it is assumed that the modelled 50 MW  parabolic trough power plant would be very similar in other parts of the world.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: - 50 MW solar thermal parabolic power plant; - Dataset modelled for the location "Upington, South Africa", Direct Normal Irradiance: 2719 kWh/m2a; - Air cooling; - collector field area: 600'000 m2; - thermal heat storage capacity: 1100 MWhth / ca. 6 hours ;- hot and cold two stage nitrate salt thermal storage system;-  full load hours: 5379 hours/year; - steam mass flow rate: 105 kg/s;
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
This dataset has been extrapolated from a dataset modelled for the location Upington, South Africa. 
The original data modelling a 250 MW power plant have been scaled down with parameter specific linear and non-linear equations to represent a 50 MW plant design. 
Uncertainty has not been adjusted as it is assumed that the modelled 50 MW parabolic trough plant would be very similar in other parts of the world.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is entirely based on the detailed life cycle inventory as presented in the dissertation report by 
Telsnig, Thomas. 2015. Standortabhängige Analyse und Bewertung solarthermischer Kraftwerke am Beispiel Südafrikas. Forschungsbericht. Band 123. ISSN 0938-1228. Institut für Energiewirtschaft und Rationelle Energieanwendung, Universität Stuttgart, Germany. 
The basics of that extensive report written in German as well as the procedure of bringing the data in that report into ecoinvent format are summarised in a report (in english) on the concentrated solar power datasets available on the ecoinvent ecoQuery webpage. 
Further, data in Telsnig 2015 are not shown explicitely for the downscaled 50 MW parabolic trough power plant. This gap is filled in the ecoinvent report.

defaultProvider.category: F:Construction/42:Civil engineering/422:Construction of utility projects/4220:Construction of utility projects

exchanges.description:
Heat needed for backup firing per 1kWh of net electricity produced. For the system as modelled in Telsnig 2015 for the location Upington, a co-firing rate of 9.6% of total gross electricity production has been calculated. The parasitic losses amount to 10.4% of the gross electricity production. 
As many systems run on natural gas as backup power source, heat from natural gas is assumed in this dataset as an input.

exchanges.description:
Water used for cleaning the mirrors. 
Various references indicate a water need for these cleaning activities between 0.04 and 0.12 l/kWh, with several references mentioning 0.09-0.1 l/kWh, so that a value of 0.1l/kWh was chosen for this dataset. 

Boukelia, T.E., Mecibah, M.S., Kumar, B.N., Reddy, K.S. 2015. Investigation of solar parabolic trough power plants with and without integrated TES (thermal energy storage) and FBS (guel backup system) using thermic oil and solar salt. Energy 88 (2015) 292-303

Fernández-García, A., Alvarez-Rodrigo, L., Martínez-Arcos, L., Aguiar, R., Márquez-Payés, JM. 2014. Study of different cleaning methods for solar reflectors used in CSP plants. Energy procedia 49 (2014) 80-89

Moreno Merino, L., Imbern Fernández, N., Durán Valsero, J.J., Aguilera, H. 2018. Journal of Environmental Management 206 (2018) 409-417.

Raza, A., Higgo, A.R., Alobaidli, A., Zhang, T.J. 2016. Water recovery in a concentrated solar power plant. AIP Conference Proceedings 1734, 160014 (2016)

System Advisor Model Version 2016.3.14 (SAM 2016.3.14). National Renewable Energy Laboratory. Golden, CO. Accessed October 31, 2016. https://sam.nrel.gov/content/downloads.
